Main Room.title: State of Hyper
Main Room.abstract: I'll (mafintosh) will give an overview on where things are technically with the Hypercore Protocol, where it's going etc.

Main Room.title: Changing to "Hyper" and the future of the Dat ecosystem
Main Room.abstract: This year, we renamed the Dat protocol to the Hypercore protocol. In this talk, we'll review what's changed and what the future holds for the Dat ecosystem.

Main Room.title: Hypercore Protocol in Rust
Main Room.abstract: First I'll talk a bit about the state of #datrs, then I'll go into how I went about implementing Hypercore Protocol in Rust: What are the challenges, what is the current state of things? Afterwards I want to have a discussion on how to move forward with #datrs.

Main Room.title: The Dat Universe - Interoperability discussion
Main Room.abstract:
How do different projects use Hypercores? How can the work with each other?

In this session we will try to give a quick overview of how the different projects in the community make use of Hypercores. We'll quickly talk about Multifeed, Hyperdrive, Corestore, Kappa Core and how these modules differ in their approach to feed and network management - and how projects like Beaker, Cabal, Cobox, DatDot, Sonar and others use them.

Then, for the main part of this session, we will moderate a discussion on different topics of interoperability and possible future collaboration points. Please feel very invited to join this discussion, both with ideas and questions on how the ecosystem could develop.

Main Room.title: Cabal's Subjective Moderation System
Main Room.abstract: People from Cabal, a peer-to-peer group chat, would like to present what we've done with our subjective moderation system with a live demonstration. The demonstration will be followed by a small Q&A around Cabal and our learnings from the moderation development process
Main Room.description:
Nick and cblgh from Cabal will have a live workshop and introduction to Cabal's basics. After the basics, the subjective moderation system will be outlined and shown.

Participants that are eager to try things out live are invited to download one of Cabal's clients before the presentation:

**Cabal Desktop**
- mac: `brew cask install cabal`
- linux/windows: [https://github.com/cabal-club/cabal-desktop/releases/](https://github.com/cabal-club/cabal-desktop/releases/)

**Cabal's terminal client**
- `npm i -g cabal`

persons.biography:
Alexander Cobleigh, cblgh, is a Malmö-based instigator of non-commercial projects having created & finished 30+ projects over the past 8 years. He's currently one of the main contributors of Cabal, a peer-to-peer distributed group chat, and he's also co-running a hackerspace in Malmö called Lodis, as well as co-starting an organic farm on the outskirts of Malmö. 

At the end of 2019, Alex quit his position at a cybersecurity startup to begin a 2-year sabbatical focused on getting user-friendly peer-to-peer projects out to the broader public. He recently finished researching a trust-based capability management system called TrustNet. If you want to support cblgh's independent research, you can: https://cblgh.org/support.html

He is an active member of both the Dat Consortium and the European Scuttlebutt Consortium, having been part of both since their initiation in the autumn of 2019.

Nick Warner is a new media artist, technologist, and developer dedicated to designing and building excellent products and experiences that shift dystopia culture to sustainable healthiness, happiness, and helping everyone find joy. Nick's work focuses on making technology, artistic expression, and communication more accessible and fun. Examples of Nick's professional work include designing, 3D modeling, and programming a living, digital replica of Times Square in the Second Life metaverse for Samsung, building App Store Top 10 mobile apps for brands such as Ford Motor Company, American Apparel, and sportsYou, and creating interactive, multimedia web experiences for Estee Lauder, Aveda, MAC Cosmetics, Lexmark, Yellow Pages, and The Game Awards. Nick has worked with startups, enterprise businesses, nonprofits, and open source communities and he is actively working to divert technological dystopia from overcoming the human experience. Nick Warner knows it can be done with efficient engineering, smart human-centered design, and a vision focused on joy.

Main Room.title: DatDot - how do can we host hypercores peer-to-peer
Main Room.abstract: A walk through the DatDot project - from the concept for p2p hosting, through the technology behind it and its biggest challenges.
Main Room.description:
DatDot is a Distributed (peer-to-peer ) Hosting Network.

https://datdot.org/#doc

Main Room.title: The Latest in Beaker Land
Main Room.abstract: A quick overview of the Beaker's current status, what's new, and what's coming

Main Room.title: The p2pcommons: A distributed information layer for research
Main Room.abstract: The peer-to-peer commons (p2pcommons) is a set of standards for Hyperdrives to improve information sharing, especially in scholarly research. In this short presentation, I will introduce the core concepts of the p2pcommons (e.g., provenance, modules), why it is relevant for scholarly research, and I highlight some of the libraries we provide to develop software utilising the p2pcommons.

persons.biography: Researcher and director at Liberate Science GmbH. My background is in psychology, applied statistics; I've specialised in meta-research, library- and information sciences. [My PhD dissertation](https://doi.org/10.31237/osf.io/4wtpc) focused on understanding and building sustainable science.

Main Room.title: Inclusive indexing of research outputs through decentralized web
Main Room.abstract: The primary goal of this facilitated discussion is to spark conversations and thoughts on the ways new knowledge is currently indexed, searched and integrated.
Main Room.description:
The currently available indexing services are based on peer-reviewed journal articles (Medline, Scopus etc), preprint focused (Prepubmed) or text based (Google Scholar, Microsoft Academic). Such indexing excludes the visibility of other non-traditional outputs such as data sets and figures, and at times peer-reviewed articles from select fields and indigenous communities. Academic status quo practices act as gatekeeper of knowledge by ranking research outputs as well as deciding which forms of knowledge become valid. 

Intersectional approach will be used to refine an idea for a community owned platform to capture and search traditional as well as non-traditional research outputs with a persistent digital identifier.

Main Room.title: 'Digital Sovereignty' huh?
Main Room.abstract: Sovereignty is popping up over the P2P space. But what do we mean by it? Some views and research emerging from cobox.cloud. co-presented with Jaya Klara Brekke (@jayapapaya) and Dan Hassan (@dan_mi_sun)
Main Room.description:
'Digital sovereignty' huh?

Lately, states have been calling for it, start-ups have been pitching with it, and communities have been building for it. 

...but do we all mean the same thing? 

and what is some of the historical baggage that the term 'sovereignty' brings with it?

persons.biography:
Expert advisor to the European Commission on Distributed Ledger Technologies. ESRC fellow at Durham University, with 15+ years working on design and economic justice of technology infrastructures.

Magma Collective co-founder, Design, UX/UI, Crypto-economist, Research

Main Room.title: Funding Opportunities in Europe
Main Room.abstract: An overview over the open calls in the Next Generation Internet, manufacturing, artificial intelligence and more. For projects in need of funding.
Main Room.description:
The mission of FundingBox is to connect creative minds with the right business opportunities in Europe. As such I would like to share with you insight into the open calls we manage as well as into other funding initiatives

Discover through this session public funding opportunities from the European Commission in several fields: manufacturing, robotics, automation, Next Generation Internet, artificial intelligence, EdTech, and more. We will also explore benefits beyond funding: acceleration, training and mentoring from experts, internationalisation, networking and more.

persons.biography: David Seoane is a Programme Manager at FundingBox with 12 years of experience on fundraising in EU programmes, including proposal preparation and evaluation, and partner search in innovation funding programmes: H2020, INTERREG, ERASMUS+, and LIFE Experience. Managing several EU funded projects under Next Generation Internet, Smart connectivity, Smart manufacturing and Smart grids initiatives.

Pablo Mondragón Fernández is a Marketing Specialist at FundingBox. With a background in Public Relations and Corporate Communications professional with global experience in the world of communications. During the last 6 years, he has been working in Journalism, PR, and Social Media Marketing in the USA, Brussels, Italy, and Spain. He is currently involved in the communication of different EU initiatives that offer funding opportunities to SMEs and start-ups in fields such as manufacturing, industry 4.0, Next Generation Internet, GDPR, and AI, among others.

Main Room.title: Building a P2P Web (with Dat!)
Main Room.abstract: The developer of the Gateway mobile browser will be discussing the process of building a fully p2p web. First by breaking down the current internet environment and its larger physical context, then exploring how we can sustain the potential change in power that p2p projects like dat have introduced.
Main Room.description: The developer of the Gateway mobile browser will be discussing the process of building a fully p2p web. First by breaking down the current internet environment and its larger physical context, then exploring how we can sustain the potential change in power that p2p projects like dat have introduced.

Main Room.title: Introduction to Agregore - a minimal P2P web browser
Main Room.abstract: This talk will introduce a new web browser, Agregore, and it's ideas about leveraging HTTP-like semantics to bring p2p protocols to the web.
Main Room.description: This talk will go over Agregore, why it was built, how it works, it's goals, and the ideas behind using `fetch()` interfaces for peer to peer protocols.

Main Room.title: Building a network library
Main Room.abstract: Libraries provide a way for knowledge to be structured and made available to all.  As datasets become as important as books how will a library make it possible to find all the datasets?  We will present and demo an implementation of a network library using hypertrie.
Main Room.description: Librarians invented ways to describe knowledge, initially for books and manuscript and created structures to describe the content that are shared openly.  In a digital age libraries need to structure knowledge of images, video, code and datasets etc.  These come from many authors and on a daily volume hard for humans to keep pace with.  Inspired by projects like https://www.researchobject.org/  how would such thinking work on peer to peer infrastructure?    We will demonstrate working code of a network library ( https://youtu.be/N-Ak9mvmZZM )  that creates a set of 'smart' reference contracts that describe datatypes, computations, visualizations and modules that allow for the creation of network experiments.

persons.biography: James Littlejohn is a hacker, entrepreneur and peer to peer technologist.  Currently, working on building a DIY science network at the healthscience.network project. This involves introducing a new protocol to coordinate the participation in network experiments.  He was an early adopter and developer using bitcoin, ethereum and maidsafe etc. His interest in Peer to Peer technologies developed during his Economics degree from Aberdeen University in 1995 which he followed with three entrepreneurial ventures in fintech, e-commerce and ptop text data mining

Denis Parfenov is a founder of the Data Management Hub and co-founder of the Open Knowledge Ireland. He is also a member of the Creative Commons Global Network and a member of the Open Data Governance Board. 

Denis is passionate about empowering evidence-based decision-making by enabling the universal free flow of data with trust through employment of openly licensed distributed data infrastructures. 

Denis is a keen photographer, an avid slackliner and an unconditional dog lover.

Main Room.title: Using Dat & the Hyper Stack in Agroecology
Main Room.abstract: Regenerative Agriculture, Agroecology, Conservation Ecology, and Urban Resilience increasingly make use of off-grid technologies; I'd like to review some of the ways in which Dat / Hyper and a 'local first' approach might be used in these contexts, with a particular focus on farming.  More description of these projects in general at https://edgecollective.io/

Main Room.title: Introducing Idili: A Portable Personal Data Store
Main Room.abstract: Idili is a personal data storage and social sharing platform, run on a portable computer such as a Rasberry Pi. The plan is to use dat/hypercore for decentralized identity management and to find a way to use it for data sharing purposes at least in part.
Main Room.description:
Idili is just reaching a minimal viable product point and I'm looking forward to introducing it to people and finding collaborators.

The current codebase is available at https://git.sr.ht/~rschulman/idili

Main Room.title: Hypercores mapped to IPLD
Main Room.abstract: The Hypercore data structure is built on top of a Merkle tree, and can be represented as a DAG - Directed Acyclic Graph. In this presentation, we will describe the data structure, and show how to construct a representation using the IPLD (Interplanetary Linked Data) library that is used by IPFS and Filecoin (also works standalone). Finally, we will show how to implement a storage provider that retrieves hypercore data from an IPLD-based datastore.

Main Room.title: Holistic Digital Authorship
Main Room.abstract: This collaborative workshop prompts discussion around precarious and hidden labour in digital authorship and open source development. Through conversations and drawings, we will explore tensions between social purpose vs. free labour, and our atomization in a competitive content market as creators.
Main Room.description:
Inspired by Holistic Security by Tactical Tech and the Revolutionary Networked Politics presentations at transmediale, we will engage through a holistic approach that centres on self-care and the well-being of content authors. There are many topics relevant to digital publishing, such as: equitable compensations and dignified livelihoods, creative expression on moderated platforms, security and anonymity in online spaces. How does one navigate the complex environments and entrenched power structures of the Web? What is the cost of the labour asked of an individual creator and the impact on their well-being?

As an initiative of the Distributed Press project, and inspired by a surrealist parlour game, we will assemble the words and images generated during our workshop to compose a work of collective authorship to express our aspirations for the future web.

persons.biography: Mai Ishikawa Sutton is a writer and community organizer with a focus on technology, policy, and solidarity economics. She is the Associate Producer of DWeb Projects with the Internet Archive and was a co-organizer of DWeb Camp 2019. She is a Steward of Sudo Mesh, a community mesh network that also builds other open-source distributed networks in Oakland, CA. She is a Digital Commons Fellow with the Commons Network, a non-profit organization advocating for and developing policies for the commons in Europe. She was previously an organizer and writer for Shareable, and before that was a policy analyst at the Electronic Frontier Foundation focused on advocating for user rights within intellectual property rules in trade agreements and other international lawmaking institutions.

Main Room.title: Adding structured documentation to Dat
Main Room.abstract: 3 part: Presentation, workshop and planning-group-meeting with the goal to bring structured documentation to JavaScript packages.
Main Room.description:
Structured documentation have found in different ways a place in the javascript ecosystem. Be it jsdoc, flow-type or typescript definition files: structured documentation is helpful in the exploration of a project (particularly options) to people outside of the project. Both martin and sam have been working on hyper* definition files and in Hyperswarm we have a discussion open on how to add TypeScript definition files [#55](https://github.com/hyperswarm/hyperswarm/issues/55#issuecomment-607318923) that haven't found their way in the project yet.

First we will have a short ~20min presentation on important things  we learned about writing definitions files, followed by a 1h workshop to add declaration to a project and in a follow-up step we want to discuss how we can bring this practically to the whole system.

persons.biography: Sam works on privacy-preserving web-tech at Cliqz and Ghostery. On the side he an active member of the Dat community, working to bring dat protocol support to Firefox. He created the [dat-fox](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/dat-p2p-protocol/) browser extension for Firefox, and more recently [integrated native Dat support](https://0x65.dev/blog/2020-03-02/implementing-the-dat-protocol-in-cliqz.html) in the Cliqz browser.

Martin is an open-source community organizer with a background in user experience and visual coding now focusing on personal security tech. He started his Open Source career in 2004~ish with ActionScript 2 _(3 was a runtime-type-safe language)_ which is a compile-time typed languages to EcmaScript and a predecessor to nowadays ubiquitous TypeScript. And is here to share his insight over many years of dealing with type information.

Main Room.title: Making stuff with Dat-SDK
Main Room.abstract: This workshop will take people through building a simple app with the Dat SDK and making it work in the command line and on a web page.
